**
The following is a summary of the activities and results of the 15 hours of coaching and indirect 
support (5hrs direct/10hrs indirect) offered since September 2024 with the support of GrantCorps
Intern Avery Saenz:
1.Funder Relationships:  We reviewed past and potential funders and discussed 
approaches for retaining and securing additional funding partners; talked through Colo 
Health Foundation and Daniels Fund, looked together at the website to find alignment; 
reviewed and discussed Caring for Colorado Part 1 application, reviewed and provided 
comments before submission. Talked through the difference between applying to 
Government vs Foundations and the use of anecdotes, and personal connection. 
Recommendation: when talking to funders include a comprehensive summary of the 
organization's initiatives and goals;  if the foundation is interested in one specific 
program; give more details about including potential outcomes and impact of that 
program.
2.Colorado Common Grant Application  ; We developed a General Operating Template 
draft using language from past grants and information provided during our conversations.
Created strong language for the first 3 sections of the application; talked through the 
evaluation section and the importance of providing numbers served and measurable 
outcomes that can then be reported on once the grant year is completed. We reviewed and
talked through the Colorado Common Grant list of Attachments; Recommendation: Read
through and check for consistent formatting (single spacing, spaces between paragraphs, 
4 page limit); Save all templates, grant calendar and attachments in one consistent folder, 
so everything is easy to find and update with new information.
3.Prospective Grants: Started a Grants Calendar spreadsheet for planning and tracking; 
practiced using the Colorado Grants Guide to identify potential funders; Avery 
researched and identified 8 new prospective foundations to apply to this year and entered 
details into the Grants Calendar.
Recommendations for Next Steps:  
1  Apply for the Denver Foundation's  Technical Assistance Grant; hire a consultant to support 
the organization in creating a short and long term strategic plan; to include a resource 
development plan for supporting general operations2  Based on your vision to involve youth and families in advocacy/systems change; share more 
about plans for how to do this through education and leadership.
3  Set a goal to apply for at least one general operating (GO) grant each month; expect 30% to be
funded in the first year and grow from there; ie: apply for a total of $150K to receive $50K; if the
proposal is declined ask for feedback when possible from contact at the foundation.
As I mentioned after getting  to know your programs and work; I feel confident that you are well 
positioned to secure additional and consistent general  operating grants to support all of Show and
Tell's work/programs  into the future.  
Feel free to reach out with questions and/or let me know how it is going, best of luck to you and 
everyone at Show and Tell in 2025!  
My Best   Sarah
Aspire Nonprofit Consulting LLC

column3:
Lack of staff trained in grant writing “while I've been writing grants both in my capacities as a public 
administrator and Piknik Theatre promoter for many years, all of
my training was on the job. It was valuable for me to have my 
past work validated and improved upon.  One of the most valuable
exercises was as a grant reviewer for CCI during an off year. 
That's very much what I experienced  during the GrantCorps 
training: an objective review of how to clearly and simply 
communicate a compelling case for support;  with a minimum of 
flowery language and a maximum of strong supporting 
documentation.”
Lack of information about funding 
opportunities, finding grants“having access to the Grants Guide, even for a few months, was 
eye opening. We discovered, with Amy Stahlin's support, some 
new options and new ways to approach past unsuccessful 
applications. I still have questions about how to open the door to 
funders who don't accept unsolicited applications but require a 
prior invitation. I know from past reviews of the 990s submitted 
from similar performing arts organizations in mountain resort 
communities that there are foundations who might be willing to 
listen to a Piknik Theatre proposal if they only knew we've been 
working since 2008 on the same missions they fund in Aspen, Vail,
or Telluride.
Awareness, viability, importance of arts “I take for granted that everyone knows the value of theatre , 
especially in a world increasingly enamored of ChatBot. The 
experience of real humans embodying real ideas and emotions in 
real time has become rare; or inaccessible if you look at the 
average price of a Broadway ticket. We offer free performances of
professional quality in a beautiful outdoor environment; what 
more needs to be said? Well, in a resort community infatuated 
with outdoor recreation, it's clear we've only scratched the 
surface of creating compelling arguments for supporting the 
performing arts. Thanks to your training and Amy's guidance , I 
think we can take our case for support to new levels and to new 
ears, while continuing to encourage ongoing assistance from past 
donors. One effort that Celina is leading is reaching out to our 
immigrant community and families with children who can 
connect with Piknik Theatre through our youth theatre camps 
and programs.” “Between using the grants guide, following the 
CRC and CCI newsletters, and the updates from the Yampa 
Valley Community Foundation, I think we've got a handle on 
grant applications that are open to performing arts work in rural 
communities. There's still that nagging question that invitation 
only foundations are unaware of what we do.”
Sustainability of leadership, staff at 
organization“ has been an ongoing issue as Piknik Theatre and I both have 
matured, so to speak. I recognize it's past time for younger 
hands and minds to take over leadership of the organization and 
hiring Celina as an executive director (while I remain as board 
chair and acting artistic director) is the first step. Now, we look to 
find funding support for organizational capacity as well as the 
actors, instructors, and performance related activities. Funding 
administration is never a hot button for donors but now that I'm 
no longer donating all of the organizational work, it's 
absolutely necessary. This issue is still unresolved.”
Collaboratively applying for funding – 
bringing together Performing Arts Alliance in 
Steamboat – to work together“this, too, is a recent development. I've bemoaned the silo 
mentality that's plagued local arts organizations for many years. 
Each nonprofit has jealously  guarded its list of donors with little 
interest in sharing. I think now that we're completing the region's 
first outdoor performing arts venue, there's some movement to 
join forces. Celina is exploring collaborations with the Steamboat 
Dance Theatre group and a relatively new nonprofit, 
Undiscovered Earth, is developing a small indoor performing 
space that they want Piknik Theatre and others to use.  It's 
unfortunate that the two biggest and longest established 
performing art nonprofits, the Strings Music Festival and Perry-
Mansfield Performing Arts Camp, don't want to share the 
sandbox.”
